dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: On a heavily shadowed street, two enemy Guards patrol a tactically important village block. Inside the most Prominent building, a party is in Progress, music wafting out into the street. The two Guards meet at a corner near the party's entrance, one loaning a cigarette to the othe Then they reverse their directions, walk apart, the Secon Guard disappearing into the darkness of the night. Titles begin. Suddenly, Jack Flack, everything a spy should be, swoops into view, riding a square American-flag parachute down from a nearby rooftop. Red, white, and blue cut through the darkness as he lands directly on top of the First Gua The parachute envelops them both. Two bodies thrash withi the silk. A moment later, Flack steps out, glances down t empty street. He wears a pair of tight pants and a beauti fully cut brown leather jacket, molded perfectly to his broad shoulders, tapering to a tight fit around his slend waist. . He pushes a hidden button on his jacket, and, with a whoo the parachute repacks itself instantly back into the jack showing not even a Lump. TITLES “CONTINUE. ©” The Second Guard turns around, heads back toward the part building. Jack Flack strolls nonchalantly up to the Second Guard, w challenges him.

dialogues.speaker: SECOND GUARD
dialogues.text: (in Russian) Halt! Identify yourself. A moment of tension is followed by Jack Flack suavely responding by pulling out a silver cigarette case, gettin out a cigarette.

dialogues.speaker: JACK FLACK
dialogues.text: (in impeccable Russian) Do you have a light?

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: The Second Guard looks suspicious, pumps the action on hi rifle. Jack Flack blows a feather-tufted poison dart from his cigarette and into the neck of the Second Guard, who instantly stumbles and falls. TITLES CONTINUE. An expensive period limo pulls up. Out of it steps a villainous Iranian (with an uncanny resemblance to Khomei arm-in-arm with the lovely Lady Gillingham, a voluptuous Englishwoman. They are followed by a fat Soviet diplomat, who carries a thin black briefcase chained to his right arm. From the shadows, Flack makes his move: just as the black bag is passing him, he whips out a cord from his Jack Fla spy watch, with the same action used to start a chainsaw. Indeed, he is starting a chainsaw, a miniature one. Its tiny but effective blade running from his watch to his other hand. He instantly cuts through the chain, grabs th black bag, and the flexible saw retracts back into his watch. The Iranian lunges at him with a scimitar. Flack deftly kicks the knife high into the night sky, then Kung Fu kic the Iranian! Lady Gillingham draws a Luger from a bra holsterette, fires at Flack, who cleverly doffs his official hat with the shiny bulletproof-steel inner liner He holds the hat shield between himself and the bullet, causing it to ricochet off and plant itself right between Lady Gillingham's beautiful eyes. The Russian diplomat pulls one of those bowling ball-type bombs out of his pocket, its fuse already burning. He tesses it at Flack, whose spy drill kit Presents itself. instantly drills three holes in the burning bomb, inserts his fingers into it, and, exhibiting pro bowler prowess, bowls it at the diplomat and a group of soldiers, who are running in pin formation to his aid. The bomb explodes, sending them flying. Jack Flack knows enemy reinforcements are on the way, so ducks around the corner, the prized black bag safe in his hands. TITLES CONTINUE.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: is halfway down the alley nonchalantly carrying the black case when suddenly a huge steel gate seems to slam down f the sky, sealing off the alley ahead of him.

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED 3
dialogues.text: As Jack wheels and starts back the way he came, the earth rumbles beneath his feet. The source of the rumble becomes immediately clear, as tw monstrous twenty-sided, brightly colored geometric forms come rolling around the corner and directly at Flack. Frantically, the spy again reverses his direction, runs f his life back toward the newly dropped steel gate. Credits end as Flack seems destined to be crushed by the frightening geometric boulders. But just then, in the nick of time, Jack Flack is invisib lifted out of the scene. MATCH DISSOLVE To

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A lead figure of Jack Flack is being lifted out of a two- dimensional match for the location we have just seen. The are bombs, foreign agents, a limo, the black case, even t steel gate. Camera pulls back to reveal Davey Osborne, eleven, doing the lifting. He is excited about the succes of his roll of brightly colored geometric dice.

dialogues.speaker: DAVEY
dialogues.text: Twenty-four! Jack Flack's agility (X) is twenty-four -- he escapes! Camera. continues back to reveal two others sitting aroun the board game called "Cloak and Dagger." Kim Gardener is nine. Morris Coffey, thirty, is the pro- prietor of Morris's Game Emporium. He is nearsighted, ove weight and immature for his age. Kim is disappointed in Davey's success.

dialogues.speaker: KIM, (X)
dialogues.text: That's not fair! You shoulda been dead! - DAVEY , (x) (smugly) But I'm not. Jack Flack always escapes!

dialogues.speaker: KIM, (X)
dialogues.text: Dumb game!

dialogues.speaker: DAVEY
dialogues.text: You've just gotta develop better moves, Kim. You're gettin' there.

dialogues.speaker: KIM
dialogues.text: (disgusted) I don't believe it. (turning to Morris) How can he do that, Morris? I had ten times as many bullets as Jack Flack.

dialogues.speaker: MORRIS
dialogues.text: Yeah, but Flack had ingenuity and the contacts. That's better than bullets sometimes. (getting up and going to his desk) Don't feel bad, Kim. I haven't been able to beat him all summer. Davey gives a cocky shrug.

dialogues.speaker: DAVEY
dialogues.text: (eagerly) What happens next, Morris?

dialogues.speaker: MORRIS
dialogues.text: Let's leave it there for now. I'll have to come up with something better to get you with. Anyway, I gotta work on the game. Davey looks hopefully to Kim to help him convince Morris keep playing.

dialogues.speaker: KIM
dialogues.text: Don't look at me. I'm sick of getting killed.

dialogues.speaker: DAVEY
dialogues.text: We could trade. I'll give ya extra gas masks and a bulletproof vest. -

dialogues.speaker: KIM
dialogues.text: No way! You never get hurt. It's no fun, Davey looks curiously around the shop, spies a new set of quality walkie-talkies, picks one up, flicks it on, getti a squawk.

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: Morris, always an easy mark, looks to Davey, then to Kim, who is just learning to talk on her instrument.

dialogues.speaker: KIM
dialogues.text: (on walkie-talkie; clowning) Hel-lo, everybody! She giggles with delight at the sound of her voice on the radio. Morris digs some cash out of his pants' pockets.

dialogues.speaker: MORRIS
dialogues.text: You guys want a real assignment?

dialogues.speaker: KIM AND DAVEY
dialogues.text: Yes!!

dialogues.speaker: MORRIS
dialogues.text: You two got bus passes?

dialogues.speaker: DAVEY
dialogues.text: Yup. Kim holds hers up. The invoice on the top of Morris's pile is from Data Poin Corporation, makers of electronic games.

dialogues.speaker: MORRIS
dialogues.text: Go over to, ah...Data Point and pick me up some o' those video game mailers. Half-dozen. Morris hands the money to Davey, who looks a little disap pointed.

dialogues.speaker: DAVEY, (X)
dialogues.text: Can't ya give us somethin’ better than than that? Something exciting, like Cloak and Dagger, only real.

dialogues.speaker: MORRIS
dialogues.text: (thinking, inventing) Okay. (leans closer, whispers) Infiltrate their eighth level...go to their vending machine.

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: MORRIS (Cont'd) (melodramatic pause, looking around for possible witnesses). Bring me back a pack of Twinkies. There's a secret message inside. (even more mysteriously) And don't let anybody see you. Anybody. Davey grabs his backpack, throws it on. (X)

dialogues.speaker: DAVEY
dialogues.text: You comin'?

dialogues.speaker: KIM
dialogues.text: Not if you're gonna be embarrassing.

dialogues.speaker: DAVEY
dialogues.text: I won't. Davey pulls several items out of his backpack: a realisti Walther PPK quirt gun, a bottle of Monster Blood, a softb and a pocket knife.

dialogues.speaker: DAVEY
dialogues.text: Let's see... (referring to each item above, in order) -gun...ammo...grenade...dagger.... He starts loading his squirt gun with the Monster Blood.

dialogues.speaker: KIM
dialogues.text: Now what're ya doin'?

dialogues.speaker: DAVEY
dialogues.text: Jack Flack says always keep your gun loaded. Davey picks up the walkie-talkie again.

dialogues.speaker: DAVEY
dialogues.text: (to Morris) Can we try these out?

dialogues.speaker: MORRIS
dialogues.text: Yeah, just don't break 'em. Kim and Davey are delighted. They run out of the back roo CcuT TO

dialogues.text: . Good, ‘cause. I'm. not walkin' up. Two men in dark suits, Opbst and Haverman, stop beside them, also waiting for an elevator. Already threatening i appearance, we can see that Davey's imagination is runnin wild about them. But then it stops being fantasy, as Haverman shoves back his suit coat and hikes his pants. Davey is at eye level to the man's waist and finds himself staring at a loaded -38 in a belt holster. His eyes widen. Davey tries to get Kim's attention to tell her about the gun. He can't. He tries coughing. She looks oddly to Davey, who is looking even more oddly to her.

dialogues.speaker: KIM
dialogues.text: (embarrassing Davey) What's the matter now?

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: Davey walks away, gestures for her to follow, just as another elevator dings its arrival. Kim hesitates, finall follows Davey. Opbst and Haverman get on the elevator, having taken no further notice of the kids.

dialogues.text: (nodding at the closing elevator doors) That guy had a gun. A real gun.

dialogues.text: (really aggravated) Oh, Davey, would you stop it?!

dialogues.speaker: DAVEY
dialogues.text: (still staring at the doors) Honest! I saw a gun. The doors to another elevator open. Passengers exit.

dialogues.speaker: KIM
dialogues.text: (refusing to miss one more elevator) You're really being a jerk. She hurries to her elevator, just makes it. Davey follows her.

dialogues.speaker: DAVEY

dialogues.speaker: KIM
dialogues.text: (handing it back) Thanks, anyway. Davey, watches the doors close Kim in, then turns his gaz to the fire doors. cuT To

dialogues.speaker: DAVEY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Davey is still climbing, now lowering the antenna on his radio, aware that he has been shut off by his partner. He looks miffed. From 0.S. comes a strong, resonant male voice.

dialogues.speaker: FLACK, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: Your friend cut off radio contact, did she? Davey stops, sees Jack Flack materialize out of thin air. He looks real and man-sized. He's just as winded as Davey but he's everything a spy should be, at least as a child would imagine it: tall and slender, wearing a black turtl neck and leather jacket with a bulge under the armpit whe his Walther PPK hangs ready and waiting. But it is his face that is most distinctive. Chiseled granite with two cold, pitiless eyes.

dialogues.speaker: DAVEY
dialogues.text: Oh, hi, Jack.

dialogues.speaker: FLACK
dialogues.text: Some people just don't know how to act on a secret mission. We're better off handling this one on our own.

dialogues.speaker: DAVEY
dialogues.text: Yeah, I guess so. Davey follows Jack Flack up the stairs. Both spies draw their Walther PPKs and proceed. (Xx)

dialogues.text: This reminds me of my assignment down in Maracaibo... (pause) We were surrounded by hordes of angry mercenaries...all I had on me was my switchblade and a ball of string...What's the matter? Flack notices that Davey has lost interest in the story ( momentarily. The boy is distracted as he notices in the opposite mirrored building that Jack has no reflectio Then Jack notices, trying to make out what had Davey's interest outside. They continue climbing.  12

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Davey turns the landing, starts up the stairs toward the eighth floor. We no longer see Flack. Davey freezes, staring up at the dying man, Murdoch.

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED 12
dialogues.text: Murdoch sees Davey and stumbles to a halt, reaching out t support himself against the boy, causing Davey's backpack spill much of its contents: the lead Jack Flack, his soft ball, his bottle of Monster Blood, his radio, etc. Murdoc stares at the frightened boy. He speaks in a death rattle his eyes burning into Davey.

dialogues.speaker: MURDOCH
dialogues.text: Help me --- The boy can only stare at him in horror. Murdoch grabs hi shoulder. He thrusts a tape cartridge into Davey's hand.

dialogues.speaker: MURDOCH
dialogues.text: (dying) Here. Whatever happens, don't let them get it. They have to be stopped. Davey glances down to find a Donkey Kong game cartridge i his hand. Before he can ask any questions Murdoch speaks through a cough that flecks the side of his mouth with bl

dialogues.speaker: MURDOCK
dialogues.text: Tell the FBI: one million two {X) hundred thirty-seven. The steel fire door bangs open on the floor above. Murdoc glances up fearfully, then back at Davey.

dialogues.speaker: MURDOCH
dialogues.text: {pushing Davey down the stairs) Run! Suddenly two silent slugs slam into the dying man. They whip him around and catapult him back first ever the stai way railing. As Davey watches in horror, Murdoch's body falls seven flights down the stairwell, bouncing off railings and walls to land with a sickening thud at the bottom, far below. Davey looks up to see where the shots came from. Peering down at him from a railing on the floor above are Haverma and Opbst, the two men from the elevator. Opbst has a Lug with a silencer on it in his hand, still smoking. He aims at the boy, about to fire. Davey grabs his backpack and whatever spilled items he ca quickly salvage, missing the softball. He whirls and plunges down the stairs, spoiling Opbst's shot. The killers bound down the steps after him.  13

dialogues.text: (carefully) Psychological |. .? (pause) For a whole hotr, all he'd tell us was his name, jank, and serial number. (shaking| his head) The tougher we got, the tougher he got. Not that 'd ever get really tough on a kid. \But if it hadn't been for: the little girl, we'd never have gotten him Officer? (pause) Davey's a good kid.| I know you must hear that a lot, but he is. He's going through tough time right now. He just|lost his mother. We're still both ad lusting.

dialogues.speaker: LT. PIO GUARDIA
dialogues.text: (on the steps) I'll say one thing were at war, I'd wa yr him. If we him on my side.

dialogues.speaker: HAL
dialogues.text: (shaking hands) Thank you.

dialogues.speaker: LT. DIO GUARDIA
dialogues.text: You just have [to convince him we're not at war. Hal is only too familiay with Davey's problem. We can see it in the disgruntled lgok on his face.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's more a refuge than it is a bedroom. The walls are dotted with fantasy posters, the shelves filled with mode airplanes, tanks and fantasy role-playing games like Dungeons and Dragons, Traveller, and Blitzkrieg. The plac of honor on the desk is taken up by an Atari and a TV. Davey sits in front of a dresser mirror Playing with toy soldiers. After a moment, there is a soft knock on his door. Davey doesn't respond. A moment later, the door creaks open. Davey's father peers in.

dialogues.speaker: HAL
dialogues.text: Ready to talk? Davey sits up. Hal joins him on the bed.

dialogues.speaker: HAL
dialogues.text: Now...tell me about the spies. (X)

dialogues.speaker: DAVEY
dialogues.text: One of 'em was real big. Like a giant. (x) The other one looked kind of Mexican or something. (pause) One of ‘em had a .38. I saw it up close. The other one had a Luger. And they both had silencers. (accusingly) You don't believe me....

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (X) Rev.

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: Hal doesn't want to answer that one.

dialogues.speaker: HAL
dialogues.text: Did Kim see them? Davey shakes his head, discouraged.

dialogues.speaker: HAL
dialogues.text: What about the body...? Did she see that? Davey knows his credibility is shot with Hal.

dialogues.speaker: DAVEY
dialogues.text: (hurt, wanting to retaliate) I wish Mom was here. She'd believe me. ~ These are loaded words, and they immediately s sadden Hal.

dialogues.speaker: BAL
dialogues.text: Yeah...she probably would. {trying to harden, for both their sakes) But she's not. And she won't be. We have to accept that....

dialogues.speaker: DAVEY
dialogues.text: (at his most - vulnerable, sobbing) I miss Mommy! 7/22/83 18 often and He throws his arms around his father, who holds him tight rocks him tenderly.

dialogues.speaker: BAL
dialogues.text: (in a whisper) I miss her, too, Davey. I bet she knows that. I bet she can even see us right now. Davey sniffs. Hal draws back, tries phony cheer.

dialogues.speaker: HAL
dialogues.text: I have an idea...Let's talk to Doctor Sullivan tomorrow and tell him what you saw today. We'll see what he says.

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: Davey closes right up.

dialogues.speaker: DAVEY
dialogues.text: Jack Flack was right. You do think I'm crazy.

dialogues.speaker: HAL
dialogues.text: No, Davey. Not crazy. But you're under a lot of strain. Anybody would be. That's...that's why you sometimes...talk to yourself. Hunh?

dialogues.speaker: DAVEY
dialogues.text: I don't talk to myself! I talk to Jack.

dialogues.speaker: BAL
dialogues.text: (refers to games in room) Well, Jack Flack and these ridicu- lous games aren't making it any easier for you to get a grasp on everything. Hal starts picking up some of Davey's more fanciful games as though he intends to take them away.

dialogues.speaker: DAVEY
dialogues.text: No! Davey digs into his backpack.

dialogues.speaker: DAVEY
dialogues.text: (making a dare) You want to see something? You wanna see proof? I'll show you what the FBI man gave me! Davey pulls out the Donkey Kong game cartridge, waves it his father, goes to his Atari, turns it on, turns on the set, sticks in the cartridge.

dialogues.speaker: DAVEY
dialogues.text: "Donkey Kong,' right? With a flourish, he pushes the Play button. Both Hal and Davey await a dramatic revelation. Davey goes into the game, the electronic little boy on th screen trying to climb the cliff while Donkey Kong holds the damsel in distress above him and rolls boulders down the boy. As the singsong game music Plays, Davey shoots glances at his father, while trying to play the game and discover its secret.

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: "Game Over" flashes on the screen, and Hal walks to the door with an armful of games.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Wait, Dad! Let me try again. Hal, sad and impatient, walks to the TV, uses the pile of games to push its Off button.

dialogues.speaker: HAL
dialogues.text: I've got work to do. No more video games tonight.

dialogues.speaker: DAVEY
dialogues.text: But....

dialogues.speaker: HAL
dialogues.text: Dammit, Davey! I said no and I mean no. Now get ready for bed. Sadly, Hal starts to exit the room.

dialogues.speaker: DAVEY
dialogues.text: (mumbling in utter frustration, seething) I hate you! Hal stops, hurt in his eyes. He puts the games down on Davey's bed, takes a deep breath, sees Davey red-faced an in.emotional knots. Sse .

dialogues.speaker: HAL
dialogues.text: (tenderly) I know you don't mean that, Davey.

dialogues.speaker: DAVEY
dialogues.text: (poutily) You don't care about me. You never believe me. Never! Ever!

dialogues.speaker: HAL
dialogues.text: (moving closer) Davey...I know how you feel....

dialogues.speaker: DAVEY
dialogues.text: (moving away) No, you don't!

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: i8

dialogues.speaker: HAL
dialogues.text: There's a lot of me in you, Davey. More than I like to see. When I was your age, I looked at things the way you do. (mocking pride) That's why I joined the Air Force. So IT could fly planes! Wear a uniform! Be somebody! I wanted to be a hero. Davey looks puzzled.

dialogues.speaker: DAVEY
dialogues.text: (softening) But you were a hero in the war, Dad.

dialogues.speaker: HAL
dialogues.text: (arm around Davey) No, I wasn't, Davey. I just did my job.

dialogues.speaker: HAL
dialogues.text: Y'know,. when you grow up...you change. (X%) Lord knows it took me long enough to grow up, and settle down...and have you. One of the first things I found different is...real heroes don't shoot bad guys. Real heroes put supper on the table. They fix your bike. Every- day stuff. Boring stuff. The stuff nobody else wants to do, but everybody has to do. Now, I'm putting these games away. I don't want you playing with them anymore.

dialogues.speaker: DAVEY
dialogues.text: Dad, if you'd just play one with me sometime....

dialogues.speaker: HAL
dialogues.text: Good night, Davey. (X) Hal gets up, picks up the pile of games, walks out of the room. Jack Flack is suddenly there, sympathizing with Davey.

dialogues.speaker: JACK FLACK
dialogues.text: He's kinda dumb for an Air Force officer, isn't he?

dialogues.speaker: DAVEY
dialogues.text: Shut up.

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: Davey angrily hurls his toy Jack Flack across the room, t flesh-and-blood version having vanished.

dialogues.speaker: JACK FLACK, (V.0.)
dialogues.text: Ouch! Suddenly, the phone in the hallway rings. Hal's voice echoes out of his bedroom. .

dialogues.speaker: HAL, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: Get that, will you, Davey?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Davey picks up the phone. Through the open doorway into his father's room, he can see Hal packing the games he to into a chest of drawers.

dialogues.speaker: DAVEY
dialogues.text: (into phone) Hello?

dialogues.speaker: RICE'S VOICE
dialogues.text: (almost friendly) Is this David G. Osborne? Davey doesn't recognize the voice.

dialogues.speaker: DAVEY
dialogues.text: Yes. Davey just stands there, frightened.

dialogues.speaker: DAVEY
dialogues.text: Dad! Hal glances up as he closes the drawer on the role-playin games, thinking he's done with them forever.

dialogues.speaker: HAL
dialogues.text: What?

dialogues.speaker: DAVEY
dialogues.text: It's the spies. The ones who killed that man! Hal strides quickly down the hall, takes the phone from Davey's hand. Disbelief is evident in his eyes.

dialogues.speaker: HAL
dialogues.text: (into phone) Hel ---

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED 19
dialogues.text: There is evidently no one there. All he hears is a dial tone.

dialogues.speaker: HAL
dialogues.text: Did you hang up on someone?

dialogues.speaker: DAVEY
dialogues.text: (hurt, outraged) No! They hung up on me!

dialogues.speaker: HAL
dialogues.text: What did they say?

dialogues.speaker: DAVEY
dialogues.text: Nothing. They just asked who I was. (frightened) They know my name, Dad.

dialogues.speaker: HAL
dialogues.text: Davey...it was probably just a wrong number. Now, let's get you into bed! Hal takes him in his arms and holds the boy as close as h can, crooning soothingly in his ear.

dialogues.speaker: HAL
dialogues.text: Davey, Davey. It's all right. There's no reason to be upset --- Davey starts to cry, trying to crawl even closer into his dad's arms.

dialogues.speaker: DAVEY
dialogues.text: (through his tears) But, Dad, it was them. I know it was ---

dialogues.speaker: HAL
dialogues.text: (softening) You're just tired. It's way past your bedtime. He takes a step toward Davey's bedroom. The boy clings to his father's neck even tighter.

dialogues.speaker: DAVEY
dialogues.text: Can I sleep in your bed tonight?

dialogues.speaker: HAL
dialogues.text: (knowingly) Okay. If it makes you feel better.  20 21 22 23 and 24

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hal lays Davey gently in bed, staring down at his son.

dialogues.speaker: DAVEY
dialogues.text: (yawning) Those guys won't dare come in with you here. Davey is close to sleep as Hal watches. He pulls the covers over him and gazes down at his son. Davey's eyelids flutter closed. Hal kisses him gently on the cheek and walks to the light, snapping it off as he leaves the room, Plunging it into darkness.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Two cars sit in the street opposite Davey's condo, a shin black van and a pearl white Cadillac, Inside the Cadillac, Rice can be seen replacing a car Phone. He gets out and walks back to the van. Opbst sits behind the wheel, Haverman next to him peering through a pair of binoculars. Rice stops opposite Opbst, nods at th condo.

dialogues.speaker: RICE
dialogues.text: He's in there.

dialogues.speaker: HAVERMAN
dialogues.text: (lowering binoculars) So's his old man.

dialogues.speaker: OPBST
dialogues.text: Now what do we do?

dialogues.speaker: RICE
dialogues.text: We wait. He and Opbst continue to stare at the condo. Haverman resumes his surveillance with the binoculars.

dialogues.text: EXT. DAVEY'S HOUSE - pay 22 Early morning sunshine bathes the neighborhood. It's another bright summer day. 23 and 24

dialogues.text: Davey bursts out the front door, stopping his father just as he's about to climb into his old Mustang. Hal Osborne is dressed in an Air Force Master Sergeant's uniform, obviously on his way to report for duty. He stops and turns back as his son rushes up to him.

dialogues.speaker: DAVEY, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: Dad! Dad!

dialogues.text: What is it, Davey?

dialogues.text: Don't leave!

dialogues.text: Davey, I have to go to work. I don't have any choice.

dialogues.speaker: DAVEY
dialogues.text: They're just waiting for you to leave so they can get me. Hal looks around the neighborhood. No sign of strangers. Absolutely nothing looks amiss.

dialogues.speaker: HAL
dialogues.text: (patiently) Listen to me. I called Doctor Sullivan this morning. I made us an appointment for tomorrow, okay? Jack Flack materializes for Davey, unseen by Hal.

dialogues.text: (continuing) I have to work a double shift today because of that big inspection I told you about, but I'll be off tomorrow, so we'll both go, and you can tell him everything you told me about the spies.

dialogues.text: Can't I go with you? As Hal talks, Jack Flack cruelly mimicks him. Davey almos laughs at the sight.

dialogues.speaker: HAL

(climbing into car, not waiting for an answer) I took some tacos out of the freezer for you. (starts car, puts it in gear) If you need me, call me at the base. Davey nods, not wanting him to leave, but out of ways to keep him there. Hal slowly backs the car out of the drive and into the street, disappearing quickly around a corner

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Davey stops just inside the front door, listening to the everyday sounds which have taken on a newly terrifying quality. A dripping faucet, the ticking hall clock, the refrigerator motor, especially passing cars. Now that his father is gone and he's alone, there's suddenly even something spooky about the silence. It makes Davey nervou He heads for the hall.

dialogues.text: Lady Ace, Lady Ace, come in --- As he waits for a reply, his eyes fall on the Donkey Kong game cartridge. Disgusted by the memories it evokes, he tosses it in his backpack. CUT To  28

Marilyn is an attractive, friendly woman in her midthirties. The walkie-talkie nearby suddenly comes to life, blaring Dave Voice into the room.

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED

dialogues.text: Wait!

dialogues.speaker: KIM

dialogues.speaker: DAVEY'S VOICE

dialogues.text: Is he always like that?

dialogues.speaker: MARILYN

dialogues.speaker: KIM

dialogues.speaker: MARILYN

dialogues.speaker: MARILYN

dialogues.speaker: KIM
dialogues.text: Forget it. He's not your type.

dialogues.speaker: MARILYN

dialogues.speaker: KIM
dialogues.text: He's in the Army or somethin’.

dialogues.speaker: MARILYN
dialogues.text: (realizing Kim is right) Oh. Kim dives back into her bowl of cereal. Marilyn continues with the dishes.
